STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 01, 2021
Barb LaRue
Grand Traverse/Leelanau/Kalkaska DHHS
701 S Elmwood Suite 19
Traverse City, MI 49684-3185
RE: License #: CP280201153
Grand Traverse/Leelanau/Kalkaska DHHS
701 S Elmwood Suite 19
Traverse City, MI 49684-3185
Dear Ms. LaRue:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
11/29/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP280201153
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Kristine Lagios, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Grand Traverse/Leelanau/Kalkaska DHHS
Facility Address: 701 S Elmwood Suite 19
Traverse City, MI 49684-3185
Facility Telephone #: (231) 941-3900
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the
reevaluation. The placement specifications shall include all
of the following:
(a) Age,
(b) Gender,
(c) Race,
(d) Number of children preferred by the family,
(e) Characteristics of children best served by the home,
(f) Children who may not be placed in the home. The
child's racial, ethnic, and cultural identity, heritage, and
background may only be considered if an assessment of
the individual child indicates that such consideration is in
the best interests of the child.
Two of the three current foster home files reviewed contained foster home
evaluation reports that did not meet the standards of this rule. In the first file the
evaluation dated 4/30/2021 gave a recommendation for a specific child but did not
identify the characteristics associated with the child as required by this rule. In the
second file the license indicated an age range (a) of 0-2 years and the
corresponding evaluation recommended an age range of 0-3 years.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
2

One of the three current foster home files and two of the two closed foster home files
reviewed indicated a licensing recommendation was not made at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of their respective licenses. In the current foster
home file, the license had an expiration date of 05/01/2021 and information
submitted for the renewal of this license was signed/dated 06/16/2021. In the first
closed foster home file the license had an expiration date of 03/27/2021 and
information submitted for the closure of this license was signed/dated 10/01/2021.
In the second closed foster home file the license had an expiration date of
08/21/2020 and information submitted for the closure of this license was
signed/dated 08/06/2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
Two of the three borrowed home files reviewed did not contain documentation the
foster parent was willing to accept the foster child placed as required by this rule.
The agency does have a form to be signed by the foster parent to establish
compliance with this rule, but this form was not included in two of the borrowed
home files reviewed. REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited
11/20/2020 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 01/06/2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of the three borrowed home files reviewed contained a current reevaluation, but
it did not include a written endorsement of the reevaluation. At the time of the exit
conference, it was reported that the agency had endorsed the reevaluation, but they
thought a copy that was not endorsed was submitted in error.
3

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed indicated the special evaluation record
(259) was not submitted to the department within the 5 working day time period as
required by this rule. In this file the intake date was identified as 03/08/2021 and the
submission date was 03/16/2021.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
Two of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include adequate
documentation that the foster parent had been given a copy of the special evaluation
report as required by this rule. The identified intake dates for these two special
evaluations were 03/08/2021 and 08/06/2021 respectively.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
foster parent was informed in writing that they could include their written response as
an attachment to the special evaluation as required by this rule. The intake date for
this special evaluation was 08/06/2021.
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Two of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
social services worker with children in the home was provided a copy of the
completed special evaluation report. The intake dates of these special evaluations
were 03/08/2021 and 08/06/2021 respectively.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child's record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
Four of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated the foster child had at
least one change in placement that was not documented as required by this rule. In
the first file the youth had an identified change in placement 04/23/2021 and a
corresponding 69 form could not be located to document this change as required. In
the second file the youth had a change in placement 11/04/2020 without the
corresponding documentation and another change 08/19/2021 that was not
documented until 10/21/2021. The third youth had changes dated 2/23/2021 and
06/25/2021 where corresponding 69’s to document these changes could not be
located. The fourth youth had changes identified 04/23/2021 and 07/30/2021 where
not corresponding documentation could be located as well as a third change
indicated 03/27/2021 that was not documented until 06/18/2021.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
5

One of the two discharged youth records reviewed did not include documentation
related to the change in placement/discharge of this youth as required by this rule.
In this file the youth had an identified discharge date of 05/07/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated that at least one
updated service plan was not completed within the time frame established by this
rule. In the first file the youth had a service plan completed 06/21/2021 that was due
06/19/2021. A second youth had a service plan with an ending date of 05/03/2021
that was completed 05/05/2021. The third youth had a service plan with an ending
date of 04/28/2021 that was completed 08/26/2021, and a second service plan with
an ending date of 07/27/2021 that was completed 08/31/2021. REPEAT
VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited 11/20/2020 INTERIM, CAP
APPROVED 01/06/2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
Three of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated there was at least
one month where there was no documentation the social service worker visited the
foster child in the foster home or relative placement as required by this rule. In the
first file there was no documentation the required visit occurred in the months of May
and June 2021. In the second file documentation that a visit occurred in April 2021
could not be located. In the third file documentation was not located for a November
2020 visit, a May 2021 visit, and visits in September and October of 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – page 11-13 Medical Passports - All medical information
required by policy and/or law must be provided to the foster parent. This includes
copies of the medical and dental examinations (if available) and the information
required in the medical passport. For children first entering foster care, the initial
medical passport must be provided to the caregivers within two weeks of the child's
6

placement date. The actual date the caregivers receive the medical passport must
be documented in MiSACWIS.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed contained a medical passport
but no signatures were included to indicate the caregivers or legal guardian
received a copy of the medical passport. REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Previously cited 11/20/2020 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 01/06/2021.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
The agency was reminded of the importance to document in the information system
required dated signatures on required documents such as service plans, and Parent
Agency Treatment Plans in a timely manner.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period for the interim evaluation completed
11/20/2020 that was approved 01/06/2021. Areas of noncompliance identified in the
interim evaluation were 306(4), 312(4), 326(1)(a)(b)(f)(g), 418(2)(b), FOM 801, FOM
722-08C, 09, 06h, and 06b. The areas identified as repeat noncompliance as a part
of this renewal evaluation are 326(1)(b), 418(2)(b), and FOM 801.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment included a review of the previous citations and
identification of barriers to achieve compliance. Staffing issues and discipline
associated with a specific staff member were some of the specific barriers identified
as well as the impact of COVID related limitations. The assessment also included
efforts in conducting a program analysis.
Interviews
Child Welfare staff were included in entrance and exit conferences with no unusual
problems noted.
7

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
12/01/2021
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 1, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
8
